messages: 451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:01): If you put an immediate script after a deferred CSS,
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:01): the script need not see the CSS.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:01): (and CSS can be deferred without warning).
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:02): In order to provide for such a dependency,
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:02): you can put the CSS-dependent code in the style elementís load handler.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:06): Why is createScript more appropriate than createElement("script")?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:12): 451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa, what are you talking about?
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:13): he doesn't post the mailing list but instead comments here
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:14): it would be nice if he gave some context, like mentioning the thread or something
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:14): Maybe he just didn't like the tumbleweed
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:16): We do not have tumbleweed in Poland.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:17): The thread is Re: [whatwg] defer on style, depends
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:29): Unstyled content is ugly/unreadable in the following cases:
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:29): * when the text contains formulas that cannot be displayed otherwise,
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:30): * when the content uses custom fonts (e.g. when the language it is in is not supported by contemporary operating systems),
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:31): * when it uses CSS for semantic images (bad, but necessary because MSIE is broken)

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:31): looks at http://html5.validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.webforum.nu%2F and wonders whether the output would be more useful if the "downplayed errors" were implemented
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (12:32): "Use alt text infotips to describe graphics."
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:32): * when the author is HTML-incompetent (bad).
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (12:32): from MS HiG: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb545462.aspx?ppud=4
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:34): The HTML5 specification is an example of a document that is actually better viewed without CSS.
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:34): (At least, in MSIE).
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:37): gsnedders: http://validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fsimon.html5.org%2Fspecs%2Fxml-stylesheet5 could you fix this? :P

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:40): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: in the html5 reference it might be useful to list event handler attributes that are likely to be useful specifically for a certain element (e.g. those related to media elements)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:45): ie8 finally has a menu item to disable stylesheets
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:47): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, which attributes specifically?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:48): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, please file a bug or send mail http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/enter_bug.cgi?product=HTML%20WG&component=Developer%27s%20Guide
451701585f2d2833921a7b3bd274aafa (12:54): MSIE7 developer toolbar allows disabling CSS as well
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:57): Do these events have associated on[event]="" content attributes? http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#mediaevents
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:57): I can't find them in the spec
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:58): soon in a HTML 5 spec near you and such
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:58): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, were they the attributes you're talking about?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:59): if so, then they will get included in the html5 reference once Hixie includes them in the spec.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:19): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6475
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:20): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: or you could take the other approach i thought of
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:20): i.e. listing the events that are fired
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:24): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, what's the other approach you thought of?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:25): oh, do you mean "listing the events that are fired" is the other approach?
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (13:27): makes sense for HTML5 itself as well I think
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (13:28): listing events that are dispatched
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:28): if the spec lists those in the summary boxes, then that would be easier for my script to just extract them all
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:49): what's the 0xFDD0 to 0xFDEF range in Unicode for?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): other than eye of the basilisk, of course
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:51): fun, fun, fun. 0xFDD0 to 0xFDEF is allowed in XML 1.0 but gets special treatment in HTML5 NCR expansion
